Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: Product has scheduled a general brainstorming session next sprint where attendance is optional
Story: I stared at my phone, the family group chat lighting up with messages about tonight’s dinner. Mom’s excited texts, my sister’s reminders about bringing dessert, and Dad’s usual jokes all made it clear: they wanted me there. I could almost hear the laughter and smell the food already. But as I glanced at my work laptop, a new email popped up—an invite to a cross-team brainstorming session for the next sprint. Attendance was technically optional, but I knew how these things went. If I missed it, I’d be out of the loop on new features, and my input mattered. My manager always said collaboration was key, and I didn’t want to seem disengaged. The pressure built in my chest. I wanted to be a good brother, to show up for my family, but I also wanted to be a reliable teammate. I felt torn, caught between the warmth of home and the pull of my responsibilities at work, unsure which expectation I should meet.
